title: Who will win the U.S. Senate election for Georgia (Class II seat) in 2020?
preds: Some good polls out for Perdue, revising my estimate upwards for his victory. Still very tight but getting slightly more confident now.

Polling is slightly favoring Ossoff. And Trump is doing the party no favors. The November 3 results are the biggest data point suggesting a Perdue win at this point. It's what's keeping me from going higher on Ossoff.
Change (R-4): Th early turnout and Trump's call are not helping Scott.

No Democrat has ever won a runoff like this in the state of Georgia. And while the rest of the country might well see this as a referendum on the election - and the outrageously antidemocratic behavior of the majority of the Republican Party - the electorate has proven susceptible to phony charges of socialism and the hysteria inducing, fear-mongering employed by Perdue and Loeffler. I would love to be wrong about this! But I have been taught my lesson by Donald Trump. Reality will no longer satisfy my right wing friends.

Ossoff 20 > 47 
Prior to the election in November, fivethirtyeight's model had Ossoff leading 49.5 to 48.9 percent (0.6) in their polls based forecast and realclearpolitics gave Ossoff a 0.7 [1], |2] lead.  In the end the result was 47.9-49.7 (-1.8). Thus the polls were off by 2.4 or 2.5 to Perdue's advantage. 
At the moment fivethirtyeight has Ossoff ahead 49.2-47.4  (1.8) [3] and realclearpolitics 49.3 - 48.5 (0.8) [4]
Assuming the same polling error Perdue would be leading with up to 0.7 points. According to Nate Silver [5] many of the better pollster are not polling in Georgia for the runoff, decreasing the quality of the polls.
For comparison the polls in the special election are Warnock - Loeffler 49.8-48.0 (realclearpolitics [6]) and 49.5-47.2 (fivethirtyeight [3]) - a democratic lead of 1.8 or 2.2. I put this as a small Loeffler advantage based on the same polling error of 2.4-2.5. I can't reliably quantify other relevant factors such as the fraud allegations, how a runoff might draw more Republicans, the fact that control of the Senate is at stake and assume that these are captured by the polls. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-election-forecast/senate/georgia/ (using the lite model)
[2] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ga/georgia_senate_perdue_vs_ossoff-7067.html
[3] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/
[4] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ga/georgia_senate_runoff_election_perdue_vs_ossoff-7319.html
[5] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-a-split-verdict-in-georgia-isnt-that-crazy/
[6] https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ga/georgia_senate_special_election_runoff_loeffler_vs_warnock-7318.html

Ossoff  55 > 62
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/
Also, the obvious attempt of Trump to threaten GA Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, so that he would "find" votes for Trump, should mobilize Democratic voters.
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/03/us/politics/trump-raffensperger-call-georgia.html

I'm adjusting odds a bit closer to 50-50 than I originally had forecast due to subsequent polling and Perdue's inability to participate in person in the final days of the campaign due to his exposure to COVID.
It will be close and I will be wrong about one of these two Georgia races...
Revising slightly down after another poll putting Ds in the lead. Think this one will be especially close but just about favouring Rs still.

The most important data points to look at come from the November results: David Perdue Republican Party 49.7% 
Jon Ossoff Democratic Party 47.9%  Joe Biden Democratic Party 49.5% 
Donald Trump Republican Party 49.3%  Purdue beat Ossoff, even though Trump lost to Biden in the state, due to a percentage of Republicans who opposed Trump. Purdue is a fairly mainstream Republican, an incumbent, and doesn't turn off a statistically significant segment of R voters. With high turnout in this race, things are looking bleaker for Ossoff. However, there's still a chance that Trump attacks the election process for being "fraudulent" and dissuades some Republican voters from turning out this Tuesday.
Lots of uncertainty but expect it to break in GOP’s favor.
Early voting suggest Dems have the edge, and with Perdue quarantining, he is now at a bigger disadvantage.
Same reasons as cited for senate overall.

Ossof 51>55
Lates polls look good for Democrats

Polls are extremely tight at the moment and seem to slightly favour Ossoff.  However Perdue had a decent, albeit small, margin over Ossoff in the original election and he's supporting Trump's $2000 stimulus cheques which I think could be significant. Going to marginally favour Perdue for now.

+5 on Ossoff based on Georgia runoff polls. I'd guess the November election itself is still the strongest data point but polls are important to factor in as well. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/

Ossoff 45 > 51
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/
Ossoff slightly ahead in polling average, and even in very Republican leaning Trafalgar poll Nate Silver writes (https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/why-a-split-verdict-in-georgia-isnt-that-crazy/): 
This is a fairly sui generis election and it’s not clear what “fundamentals” would apply, especially in a period where Trump is a lame duck but not at all acting like one, and his approval ratings are actually worse than they were on Nov. 3. Nor is this the strongest batch of candidates; three of the four candidates (all but Perdue) have never won an election before.2 If you default to the November results, those would imply that Perdue is the slight favorite, but I don’t think that’s true of Loeffler.
Going all-in on Team Blue down the stretch. Gambler’s hunch.

The Georgia Senate runoff forecast (w/ default assumptions) of the new Open Model Project currently gives Ossoff a 37% chance of winning. They have a transparent and seemingly rigorous methodology and have recently conducted a Georgia poll too. I have no reason to think I shouldn't defer to them. https://www.openmodelproject.org/

Ossoff 50 > 45
It's  a tie in the polls but I am wondering if they, again, overestimate Dem candidates.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/
Loeffler is a bad candidate and not like by GA Republicans. The President’s refusal to sign the stimulus is hurting her. Trump continues to stoke a Republican civil war in GA.
The swings in polling make me think there is even more ambiguity (Dems +7)
It is a dangerous place to be when what you *think* will happen aligns with what you *want* to happen. Among the Georgia senate races, I know we'll get one wrong... I just don't know which one.
There is no swing against the Republicans but against Trump, Trump gone so they should get it up
Happy to be proven wrong, but I think crowd odds of only 60% means there's a lot of wishful thinking here.
Given all the variables and the close margin, I think I am going to stick to giving the Dems a 30% chance.
Polls show a race favoring Perdue and this confirms my priors.

Purdue a "traditional" type of candidate  (conservative white male) likely to gather more votes considering GA's political landscape. The general election showed that this landscape is changing, but I suspect the Democrat Ossoff  is not compelling enough for the undecided GA voter, especially given this runoff's circumstances.
The public wants change and a powerful president
Democrats have a slight edge here only because they are not threatening to sit home like some Trumptards are.

Perdue 45>50, Ossoff 55>50
due to recent pollingt https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/

Early voting 40,000 more in first day than before Nov. 3.
And by registration,majority Democratic on first day precursor of last day January 5. Dems are banking lots of votes. I predict a second small majority for Biden.
If it becomes a vote for change in an epidemic,both inside traders may be out of Senate

538 gives Ossoff a lead of 1.0% in their polling avg. RCP gives Perdue a lead of .5%. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/ and https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/senate/ga/georgia_senate_runoff_election_perdue_vs_ossoff-7319.html. Predictit has Perdue a favorite with roughly 62% chance of winning, https://www.predictit.org/markets/detail/6651/Which-party-wins-the-regularly-scheduled-2020-US-Senate-election-in-Georgia
Breakdown of demographics of the run off votes as they are coming in: http://georgiavotes.com/
Perdue is skipping debates so i guess he is fairly confident to win

Jus a microscopic edge for Ossoff, 60 > 55
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/georgia-senate-polls/

Change: Ossof (+5) Polling summarized by 538 puts this race at a dead heat. My priors and the polling error tilt it to Perdu from there, but the polls certainly suggest more uncertainty. Also, given the lack of a presidential for this election, it might be more like the midterms for which polling was pretty good. If the polling stays as is I will tighten the margin.
Damn, I haven't updated this one in a long time

Although the Dems have outfundraised the Reps, the Dems are fighting an uphill battle with Dem identity politics, defund the police and socialist messaging.  The runoff race will be tight, but the Reps will take this given deep seated work ethic, religious conservatism background in GA.

Crowd overestimates Ossoff’s chances. I agree that the pandemic and mail in voting add uncertainty, but the evidence from this week’s Athens-Clarke County runoff is that GA Republicans are continuing to turn out as usual for those people, while Democratic voters are having their usual decline in turn out.

50 > 60 for Ossof
Even R-leaning Trafalgar has him slightly ahead, consistent w other polls
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/georgia/

One point I feel should be compelling is that the prediction for the Loeffler-Warnock race is 50/50 currently, but this race is much wider. This implies that people will be ticket splitting this race (some voting for only one candidate or splitting D/R). I think this is highly unlikely. I think the vast majority of voters who feel motivated to get out to vote on jan. 5th will vote either straight D or straight R.
This is really hard to evaluate. There are a lot of moving parts and not a lot of polls.
As before, following https://www.getguesstimate.com/models/17271 with h/t to @juancambeiro

The Republican candidate almost reached 50% in the first round. I think it is more likely that Republicans are eager to block Democratic control of the Senate than that they are demoralized by all the talk about election fraud

-5 to R. New SurveyUSA poll has Ossoff +2. I'm not going to tip it in his favor based on one poll but worth adjusting on. Interestingly, scrolling back down to SurveyUSA's October 14th poll they appear to have pretty accurately matched the margins/outcomes of the two Senate seats and were pretty spot on on Warnock's vote share compared to other polls. Again, can't read too much into a couple polls because it could have been a fluke, but is perhaps a small indicator that this poll could be the most useful so far. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/senate/georgia/

Young voters (students etc.) are getting mobilized heavily.
Their share likely voting for a Democrat candidate is said to be 57% ("at least" I would add), so this particular group may skew both runoffs towards the two more Democrat senators. Degree of additional voter mobilization is key. Everyone knows what this election is about - the balance of power depends on GA -, this is going to help.
A republican collapse in faith in the integrity of voting will crater turnout.
Race is gradually shifting toward Rs being able to campaign on Senate being a check on Biden. This favors the two R candidates
The democrats need to play with the Republican tactics for this one.

I am trying a new strategy. I subtract rather than add 10% every time I read an article that favors my preferred candidate. [1] An effective way to counter confirmation bias? Let's see... [1] https://insideradvantage.com/2020/11/17/iagfox-5-poll-senate-races-locked-up-kemp-approval-sags/
Polling presently doesn't show advantage for one of the candidates. Results on Nov. 3 strongly influenced by turnout for presidential candidates, race might end up very differently.
Generally the incumbent has the advantage in a race like this, but it is likely Democrats will vote early in bigger numbers and Republicans will be hit harder by low voter turnout.

Presuming greater GOP turnout in JAN 2021. I could be very wrong about these. Aggregate turn out of the senate vote NOV 2020... 
GOP - 4709449
DEM - 4648720

The libertarian vote will most likely go to David Perdue. This will be close, but it will give him enough of the votes to get to the 50% or slightly better. Ossoff has a chance but much less likely, even while mounting a competitive campaign.

I am no longer so sure about this one. There are not a lot of analogues, but you can look at the 2019 runoff in the Mississippi Senate race: 
- The combined Republican vote on election day 2018 was R +15.26. 
- The Republican vote in the runoff was +7.26%, a swing toward blue of 8 points.
On November 3, Ossoff only lost by 1.7 points. Trump rallied for Hyde-Smith: https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/27/mississippi-runoff-trump-rallies-for-gop-sen-cindy-hyde-smith.html
Will he rally in GA for the runoff? By all accounts he couldn't care less about the Senate GOP and is focused on his various challenges to Biden's win. So that's definitely a wildcard. 
Also, 70% of Republicans don't think the election was "free and fair" since Trump lost: https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/nov/10/election-trust-polling-study-republicans  Assuming that poll is accurate, is that indicative of a lot of passion to turn out and vote in January?
Incumbent senator and special elections tend to go for the party that lost the general election.

This is kind of a base-rate guess given that Georgia has never elected a Democratic senator, Ossof trailed Biden's margin, Perdue is an incumbent, and run-offs are likely to be worse for Dems without the presidential race to drive turnout.  Things to look out for:
1) Polling
2) Is Trump going to campaign in Georgia? That would likely help the GOP further. My assumption now is that Obama will campaign in Georgia.
3) Any measure of Democratic enthusiasm.

GA has barely flipped to BLUE, but the election is a very very large poll. And Perdue won said poll by 1.7% https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/11/03/us/elections/results-senate.html?action=click&pgtype=Article&state=default&module=styln-elections-2020&region=TOP_BANNER&context=election_recirc I expect the runoff to lose several points off  the general election result. See https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/georgias-runoffs-will-determine-control-of-the-senate-heres-what-we-know-so-far/

Perdue backed out of the 3rd debate after Ossoff mopped the floor with him. I suspect that many people had already voted by that time, so that move by Perdue may not have hurt him as much. It might impact that runoff though.

Based o the history of voting in the region and the initial voter leaning in House and Senate elections the Republican Candidate will likely be elected.  The Presidential race strongly polarized voters and voter turnout typically favor Democrats but Voters likely votes their local politics in spite of presidential voting which seems to be emotionally and personality-driven over issue-driven like local elections typically are.

Michigen glich
Based on votes differences Republicans are leading, so they may win the run off, unless something changes...
Aligning my prediction for Congress and Georgia Senate

It seems that the power of incumbency is enough to create a few points of advantage.  In the runoff election for January, the libertarian votes will likely flow through to Purdue.  Baring major upsets, even continued issues with the corona virus or stock market, Democrats do not seem likely to win this seat.
What I want to know is will Purdue find his huevos and debate Ossoff again? [1] Can we launch a new GJOpen question on that? [1] https://twitter.com/ossoff/status/1321926559368912896

538 seems to have had Rep winning at 83% (pre-election), conditional on going to run-off (though maybe the number of simulations is too small for this to be reliable as not many went to a run-off). Crowd has this at 58%, so adjusting down a bit.
Higher than usual African American support for Trump.  Strong Republican base.

The polls are very close with a slight edge for Perdue, and we are less than three weeks away from the election.   However, Covid is starting to spike in what might be a second wave, and the economy is slowing.  Trump seems to understand the severity of the need for stimulus and is panicked since he cannot move enough senate Republicans to get it passed.  The most recent 538 polls average Purdue with a 2% lead since September 27.  The most recent polls have him a bit higher, except for one that has Ossoff +1 percent.    There are advantages to being an incumbent.   Yet, I think Ossoff will gain at a minimum 1 percent and a maximum 5 percent in the next few weeks.  So, lets say Purdue is + 3 right now.  Then subtract 3 for the average of the effects of coronavirus and the collapsing economy.  That makes it almost dead even.  I will still add a point for the incumbency.  So 60/40 for Purdue.   This may change to 40/60  Purdue (thus favoring Ossoff) in the next week if the unemployment new claims start rising again -- I think they will at least as bad as last week--  and, coronavirus starts to spike nationwide.  It could be 30/70 in favor of Ossoff if the coronavirus numbers start rising in Georgia.

This forecast was programmatically produced by taking the (deluxe) 538 prediction and making a calibration adjustment unless this brought probability to <10%. Boice and Wezerek (2019) find that 538's 80% predictions correspond to an 88% probability (https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/checking-our-work/). Recommended reading: Information, incentives, and goals in election forecasts, by Gelman et al. (http://www.stat.columbia.edu/~gelman/research/unpublished/forecast_incentives3.pdf)

Perdue is now up in recent polling, is the incumbent, and benefits from a low profile that keeps him relatively isolated from any blockbuster news updates that are likely coming and a relatively deep red state that is unlikely to swing blue any time soon.

The race has tightened but Republicans still have a slight edge.
The Republican has consistently let in the polls, with a few having him over 50%, plus he has significantly more cash on hand.

Special election means that if no candidate captures 50% of the vote, there will be a run-off between the top two candidates. Polling suggests that either it'll be two republicans or one democrat and one republican as the top two. Under either scenario, based on voters' historical and current preferences, looks like Republicans have a solid chance of winning. Allowing a small possibility of Democrats winning due to changes between then and now for the election.

A month ago, Ossoff was trailing Perdue 49-43 in the Monmouth Polls. But it all depends on turnout. If turnout is high, especially among historically disenfranchised voters, this could turn (as could the presidential election). It depends on whether they register for absentee ballots, and if not, whether they're able to vote on election day. It's not an easy 100% to the Republican candidate because of the possibility of higher turnout creating a Dem win.

The highest quality recent polls on 538 give Perdue the edge. The national trend leans Democrat and Ossoff performed well in his previous attempt. I'm putting the most weight on the recent high quality polls in Georgia and giving the edge to Perdue for now. Also based on Decision Desk forecast: https://forecast.decisiondeskhq.com/senate/S2020GA02

I believe there is an undercurrent of a desperate need for conservatism in this country, and secondly people will turn out to vote Republican to help balance out the perceived threat of ballot harvesting and fraud for the Presidential election.   If the Republicans lose the presidency, I believe there will be a balance of power in a Republican majority in the Senate as well as the House.
Comes down to turn out for the presidential election. Perdue has more name recognition so if the presidential race is close, will likely be in favor for him.
This will be a tight race, with a lean toward the incumbant republican.  However, if Trump stays below 50% in GA, lean goes to the Dem (Ossoff).  I live in GA.

Georgia is turning more purple by the year and the incumbent advantage of Republicans appears to have been largely wiped away this cycle. Recent polls show the two neck and neck, with neither breaking free of the margin of error. I'll be curious to see how this one develops, but for now I'm leaning towards the historically preferred candidate based on party dynamics alone.
The Democrat has a slight chance for this seat depending on voter turnout (particular black voters) and how much voter suppression is allowed. Still an uphill battle.
